an5.54:1.1: “Mendicants, there are five times that are not good for meditation.
an5.54:1.3: Firstly, a mendicant is old, overcome with old age.
an5.54:1.4: This is the first time that’s not good for meditation.
an5.54:2.1: Furthermore, a mendicant is sick, overcome by sickness.
an5.54:2.2: This is the second time that’s not good for meditation.
an5.54:3.1: Furthermore, there’s a famine, a bad harvest, so it’s hard to get almsfood, and not easy to keep going by collecting alms.
an5.54:3.2: This is the third time that’s not good for meditation.
an5.54:4.1: Furthermore, there’s peril due to turmoil in the wilds, so the countryfolk mount their vehicles and flee everywhere.
an5.54:4.2: This is the fourth time that’s not good for meditation.
an5.54:5.1: Furthermore, there’s a schism in the Saṅgha.
an5.54:5.2: When the Saṅgha is split, they abuse, insult, block, and forsake each other.
an5.54:5.3: This doesn’t inspire confidence in those without it, and it causes some with confidence to change their minds.
an5.54:5.4: This is the fifth time that’s not good for meditation.
an5.54:5.5: These are the five times that are not good for meditation.
an5.54:6.1: There are five times that are good for meditation.
an5.54:6.3: Firstly, a mendicant is a youth, young, with pristine black hair, blessed with youth, in the prime of life.
an5.54:6.4: This is the first time that’s good for meditation.
an5.54:7.1: Furthermore, they are rarely ill or unwell. Their stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold, but just right, and fit for meditation.
an5.54:7.2: This is the second time that’s good for meditation.
an5.54:8.1: Furthermore, there’s plenty of food, a good harvest, so it’s easy to get almsfood, and easy to keep going by collecting alms.
an5.54:8.2: This is the third time that’s good for meditation.
an5.54:9.1: Furthermore, people live in harmony, appreciating each other, without dispute, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.
an5.54:9.2: This is the fourth time that’s good for meditation.
an5.54:10.1: Furthermore, the Saṅgha lives comfortably, in harmony, appreciating each other, without dispute, with one recitation.
an5.54:10.2: When the Saṅgha is in harmony, they don’t abuse, insult, block, or forsake each other.
an5.54:10.3: This inspires confidence in those without it, and increases confidence in those who have it.
an5.54:10.4: This is the fifth time that’s good for meditation.
an5.54:10.5: These are the five times that are good for meditation.”
